eda_steps.step_description: Analyzed the distribution of all four numerical features (sepal and petal measurements) across the three iris species using overlapping histograms.
step_insights: Petal measurements (length and width) show clear separation between Iris-setosa and the other two species, with setosa having significantly smaller values
Sepal measurements show more overlap between species, with versicolor and virginica being particularly similar in sepal width
All features appear to follow approximately normal distributions within each species, making this suitable for various classification algorithms

dataset_description: The Iris dataset contains 120 training samples with 4 numerical features (SepalLengthCm, SepalWidthCm, PetalLengthCm, PetalWidthCm) for classifying three iris flower species. This is Fisher's classic 1936 botanical classification dataset with perfectly balanced classes (40 samples each).

columns.name: Id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each sample, not used for modeling
columns.additional_information: Row identifier that should be excluded from model training

columns.name: SepalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the sepal in centimeters, ranging from 4.3 to 7.9 cm
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature with mean 5.84 cm and std 0.84 cm

columns.name: SepalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the sepal in centimeters, ranging from 2.0 to 4.4 cm
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature with mean 3.04 cm and std 0.45 cm

columns.name: PetalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the petal in centimeters, ranging from 1.1 to 6.9 cm
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature with mean 3.77 cm and std 1.77 cm - shows highest variance among features

columns.name: PetalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the petal in centimeters, ranging from 0.1 to 2.5 cm
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature with mean 1.20 cm and std 0.76 cm

columns.name: Species
columns.description: Target variable with three iris species classes: Iris-setosa, Iris-versicolor, and Iris-virginica
columns.additional_information: Perfectly balanced target with 40 samples per class in the training set

eda_summary: The Iris dataset is ideal for multi-class classification with 4 well-scaled numerical features and perfectly balanced classes. Petal measurements provide strong discriminative power, especially for separating Iris-setosa from other species. The data shows no missing values and follows normal distributions within each class. Feature scaling may be beneficial given different measurement ranges (sepal width: 2.0-4.4 vs petal length: 1.1-6.9). The linear separability mentioned in the problem description is evident in petal measurements.
